name: Plenty Café

categories: American (New), Wine Bars, Cafes, Restaurants, Coffee & Tea, Food, Nightlife, Bars, Breakfast & Brunch
llm_reasoning: 80% - Strong alignment to coffee & cafe category evidenced by frequent explicit coffee mentions and cafe atmosphere, with 167 of 255 reviews containing category-related keywords.

text:
Plenty Cafe has a lot going for it. It's in a great location that's convenient to Center City, the decor is chic and comfortable, and their music playlist is impeccable. Although I only got a latte while I was there, the food options that I spied on the menu looked very tempting.

However, I'm taking three stars off because of a ridiculous policy that leaves a bad taste in my mouth -- they shut off their advertised wi-fi during peak hours. This bothers me for two reasons: firstly, you don't find this out until you've bought your food, settled down, and cracked open your laptop to do some work. Ugh. Secondly, turning the wi-fi off to ensure that customers get their coffee and get out as soon as possible shows that their priority is revenue rather than customer satisfaction.

There were a lot of positives -- but the only reason I splurge on cute coffee shops is to hunker down with a hot drink and get work done outside of the library for once. With so many other great, welcoming options nearby, why bother with one that wants you out the door as soon as they have your cash in their hot little hands?

Plenty is my new favorite study haven! Lofts are kind of enchanting places for me (something akin to hammocks and tree houses), and I absolutely love that Plenty has such a cute cozy little loft, one that is ideal for meeting up with friends and/or studying the afternoon away. 

Yes, the area is a bit small so it can be hard to find seating during the busy hours, but what decent coffee shop in the city doesn't have the same problem? In the upstairs loft, there are a few outlets along the bench seating and the wifi is solid (current password: drinkcoffee). 

I loveeeee their sandwiches too. I've tried out a couple and my favorite is the New Orleans, comprised of the sweet fig jam, crispy green apple, and the house smoked spicy ham - an explosion of delish flavors all together! My one lament is how long I've been purchasing drinks/food at this place and only JUST discovered that they have punchcards... But for me, I guess it's compensated for by being only 3 blocks away from my apartment and thus saving me commuting costs/effort.

I'm happy to be the duchess here for now, and intend to keep it that way ;)

My lunch plans with a friend were cancelled, so I ventured out and decided to give this place a try. I've passed by it so many times but never went in! I checked out the menu online first (to try and expedite the ordering process since this was a work lunch break) and decided I'd try the Istanbul sandwich.

When I arrived, I was a little disappointed to see that it was pretty packed - no empty seats left to dine in - so I ordered the sandwich and a chai latte to go. Latte (made with almond milk) was good, but comparable to Starbucks so nothing crazy special other than having almond milk as an option. 

As I was waiting, I looked at the menu and noticed that my sandwich was labeled as "spicy" on the menu on the wall. Yikes!! I can barely handle mild salsas... I didn't change my order though, because overhearing some other orders I learned that they were out of kale, out of bagels, out of this fig jam stuff, and out of chicken. I don't really like kale or chicken, but knowing they were running out of so many things before noon made me nervous to try and get something else.

I took my sandwich to go and ate in Rittenhouse (maybe a 5 minute walk from the cafe, and there are usually plenty of open benches to sit on), and it was pretty good, besides lighting my mouth on fire. I'd like to come back another time and try the Grilled Cheese or maybe stop in for "brunch" and get a bagel.

Overall - nice, trendy, "cozy" (read: small) place with some great menu options. Slightly overpriced (in my work-lunch opinion), but really tasty and definitely worth a shot if you're in the area. Try to get there before the lunch rush so you might be able to get a seat and/or order what you want without them running out of ingredients.

I've been in Center City all week for work and finally stopped in (twice!) for breakfast after passing it by every time I've been in the general Rittenhouse area. I really wanted to love this place, as I'm always on the market for a new cafe.

Sadly, Plenty Cafe isn't for me. My first visit I ordered an iced coffee and a bagel. The bagel was fine but could have used a more liberal hand on the cream cheese but the coffee was very watery and bland. Second visit was iced coffee (second time's the charm?) and a breakfast sandwich. Same watery almost tasteless coffee (this one tasted almost like iced tea, which was odd) and the blandest sandwich I've ever had. There was some sort of sauce on it but I couldn't tell you what it was because it literally tasted like air. For a $9 sandwich, I expect more flavor, if not more actual sandwich. 

On the plus side, the service was pleasant and I didn't feel cramped waiting for my order like many other reviewers have felt. 

With Rival Brothers fifty steps away and a multitude of cafes in the surrounding blocks, there really isn't much reason for me to come back.

So I love the other locations. This review should not reflect on them. But the service here is abysmal. We tried to come last week and there was a notebook-paper sign on the door saying they were closed 2 hours early for no reason. This week we came (because we have had rest experiences st the other locations) and sat for 30mins without anyone trying to bring us a menu or acknowledge our presence. Finally we went up to the counter and ordered drinks and food. We were told the kitchen was closed until the chef returned in 20mins. No problem, we are not in a rush, and it seemed like the chef was on a scheduled break. Over an hour later, we have since seen the chef come in, we are still waiting. We ask the waitress if the food is coming anytime soon, and she says no, the kitchen is still closed. With NO warning or update to us. She did offer us a refund, but she seemed completely unconcerned about wasting an hour of our time, and more concerned about flirting with another client. Will not be back to this location.

This place does have PLENTY of yummy options to choose from. They have coffee and breakfast things, salads, soup, sandwiches, and lunch things. My husband, P, chose the Barcelona sandwich, that I had a taste of and was delicious and very reminiscent of our vacation to Barcelona. It had the salty cured meats and hard cheese that you find all over Barcelona with some lettuce and aioli on a fresh roll. However, the roll was extremely hard to bite into. Not stale, but just a REALLY hard roll, which made eating the sandwich difficult. P also got the split pea soup, which came in a huge container topped with bacon and crème fraiche. It was pricey at $10 for one serving, but it was large and came with seemingly high quality ingredients. There are 2 reasons why I am giving 3 stars vs 4. 1 is because when you're ordering for take out there isn't really a good place to stand. Therefore, while you're waiting, you're in the way of wait staff delivering meals and other patrons trying to find a good spot to bunker down with his or her laptop. The second reason is because of the price. $14 seems steep for a sandwich. But now i know and if I visit again maybe I'll try to snag one of the outside tables and stay out of the way while I'm enjoying my meal.

I used to go here all the time because I live in the neighborhood, but the quality of the food and the customer service has taken a significant dive and I doubt I will ever go back.

I ordered a couple of sandwiches to go. After about 20-25 minutes of waiting, I finally got my stuff. I went home, looked at one of the sandwiches (a salmon sandwich), and couldn't find the meat. I took it apart and dug around and there was maybe salmon on a third of the sandwich. I took it back and one of the guys (maybe the manager, I have no idea), yelled from the kitchen across the restaurant to me that he'd remake it but it would have the same amount just actually spread over the entire sandwich. I was frustrated because I consider myself to be pretty low maintenance and don't send food back unless there's something really wrong. I've never had a snarky response in a restaurant like this before and was so floored I told them not to worry about it and left the restaurant. I will not return.

Hands down the best spot for coffee and a sandwich in the neighborhood! 

The sandwich selection is unique and of top quality from local vendors. Local roasters are also featured; Rival Bros., ReAnimator and La Colombe, and the baristas know how to make a proper cup including pour over. 

My go to sandwich selections are the Tasso Ham and Chicken Salad. The Tasso Ham features house cured and smoked pork shoulder that is thinly sliced and nicely spiced. The Chicken Salad has chunks of chicken pulled together with an awesome whole grain mustard mayo. Other sandwiches that are unique and definitely worth a try are the Seoul (bulgogi short rib) and the Matambre (grilled filet w/ veggies). I have to mention that the rolls are incredible; crunchy on the outside and doughy on the inside. The best kind for sandwiches. 

The atmosphere is modern with an organic feel due to wooden floors and walls. There are tables in the front of the restaurant as well as a cozy upstairs balcony. There are even a few outdoor tables and an indoor bar facing a large window for people watching. 

So, don't come here expecting run of the mill coffee service and thrown together sandwiches; they do things a step above here. If you have an appreciation for a properly made cup of coffee and a sandwich made with lots of thought and attention to detail, this is a place that will become your new go to.

I stopped by for the first time this afternoon. The space is very cute and I was able to get a seat right away, but it was incredibly hot inside. The servers/baristas weren't rude by any means, but also weren't personable at all. 

One of the servers dropped my cheese plate without silverware (though I'm not sure if I was supposed to grab that myself). When she came back with it, I asked what the cheeses were. She replied with, "umm I think that one is cheddar". I just sat there looking at her until she said she would go find out. It's weird to me that you would start service without knowing what the cheeses are but hey, we've all been there and slipped up once or twice. So she came back and said "there's a cheddar, a gouda, and a bleu cheese." Well yeah, I can tell that by looking at it. No explanation of the name, location, type of milk, profile, nothing. No mention of the mystery spreads on the plate. She went back behind the counter and that was my last interaction with anyone. I get that it's a café, but it is kind of strange when you sit down for lunch and the staff is too busy on their phones to pop over and check how it is. 

The food itself was perfectly fine. Not bad, but nothing to get excited about. Certainly not worth $17. And I did never figure out what the mystery spreads were. 

All in all, I probably won't be back. Philly has too many other great eateries with service staff that is enthusiastic and educated on the product.

Popped in this past Sunday afternoon at around 2 pm-got a table for 3 with no wait. Server was friendly and helpful in terms of rearranging tables for our needs. 

We ordered quickly, and food came out beautifully presented (and very tasty!!) in about 20 minutes. I had the Provence salad ($11, lemony dressing and grated pecorino over shaved fennel, artichokes, roasted red peppers, and mixed greens) + tuna nicoise and the soup of the day ($8), a tasty mushroom barley blend with lots of other veggies and chili. My salad was pleasantly tangy and dressed just the right amount. I loved the way the tuna was finely shaved on top. The soup seemed a little small for being $8 but was hot and hearty. Would not have been enough for a meal alone.

My dining companions got the Tel Aviv salad ($12, cumin-orange vinaigrette over toasted pistachios, kale, arugula, farro, pickled radish, and beets) + chicken and the grilled cheese (gruyere!) and cup of tomato bisque ($14). They both got coffee (there was an interesting and varied selection of options, including nitro cold brew) and were happy. 

Seemed like a good place for a casual lunch or brunch...including a casual lunch or brunch date! Place had a nice hum to it. I'd go back.

This place has gone significantly downhill in recent months.  I used to frequent this place at least once a week because I work around the corner.  But over the past few months, the food quality has slipped and the wait times have become outrageous.

Case in point: today I came in on my way to the office to grab a coffee and sandwich.  The coffee was made on the spot but I waited more than 30 minutes for my sandwich.  During those thirty + minutes, four orders came out.  Four.  And one of those was a caviar delivery.  Think about that for a minute.  These weren't huge orders.  One was a single take out.  The caviar order was a single bag, not sure how many sandwiches were in there but not more than 2-3.  Another was a family of three eating in.  Another was a single sandwich eating in.  So in more than thirty minutes, that kitchen managed to crank out 1 salad, and somewhere between 3 and 5 sandwiches.  That is pathetic.  That is not a kitchen under strain.  That is an incompetent kitchen. 

When I got my sandwich, it was a long way from the quality that used to be expected there.  Though it's worth noting that this place has never served a sandwich worth waiting 30 minutes for.  I got one of my old standards, the New Orleans.  But this time there was too much jam (like waaaaay too much) and very little meat.

I'm not sure I'll be going back.  This long wait was my longest to date but the place has been trending that way for some time (weekday lunch was becoming a regular 20 minutes but that was far more crowded than today).

So I've eaten my last sandwich from these people.  I hear they finally opened in queen village.  I guess they haven't learned that expanding too fast causes everyone to lose.

Plenty is a well-priced café (given the area it is located) offering well-above average beverages and café eats. It offers gluten-free & vegan options, salads, catering, and probably more. The staff and ambiance here are equally nice, and the giant archway, interior & two floors alone make this place worth a stop.

Their drip coffee passed my litmus test in that it isn't nauseatingly bitter like *ahem* other cafés. It indeed is good enough, but for show-stopping coffee, I prefer La Colombe's & Elixr's when in the area.

I ordered breakfast and lunch together as to go. Service was OK speed since there was a small line, but the rapport at the end sealed the deal.

The smoked salmon sandwich, wow. It's a solid gourmet breakfast choice. The caper dill cream was light, tangy & complimented with the egg base and saltiness of the salmon. The caramelized onion gave it that unexpected sweet rich flavor note that catapulted the whole sandwich. Basically, adding the onion to the sandwich is like adding nutmeg to bechamel sauce: it's so much better with that extra something. Since then I've made a similar sandwich, and it came out almost as good as having someone else make it (admit it, it's better that way).

The caprese sandwich was simple and light, but came out muddled unfortunately. The mozzarella was pretty fresh, but the tomato juices absorbing into the ciabatta distracted from the balsamic and the basil in the too-garlicky-to-eat-at-work pesto. This effect made it seem like a Spanish inspired sandwich that was missing jamon serrano or something.

I'm glad I gave this café another shot, since my first choddy experience at the other joint. I recommend this place, as it is a quaint escape from the city. But by no means is it not neck-to-neck with other establishments in Rittenhouse.

Plenty Cafe is my go-to spot for easy Sunday mornings paired with a great book. 

After trying this place once, it's slowly turning into my Sunday haven where I can hide away, devour some delicious food, and enjoy my morning sipping on a warm beverage on this cold dreary days. 

The space is insanely cozy, with wood paneling all around, and an smaller upper level loft - my favorite place to sit. The menu consists of many sandwiches, with a few other dishes as well, and breakfast options including sandwiches, granola, and some egg dishes. So far, everything I've tasted has been delicious, without anything being too heavy or gluttonous that it'll ruin your day. 

The PLENTY BREAKFAST SANDWICH takes your typical breakfast wich to the next level by piling sausage, eggs, and cheese on a buttery and sweet brioche bun! This wasn't my favorite, but I enjoyed having a few bites of my boyfriends. 

The EGG WHITE is my current favorite breakfast sandwich. A lighter take on a breakfast sandwich with flavors I wouldn't expect for breakfast. Egg whites are topped with diced grilled squashes, slices of avocado, roasted red pepper aioli, and pecorino cheese to add a unique twist to the sandwich. It's served on the multigrain, which is my favorite. The bread is thin, but lightly toasted to give it the perfect chew, with seeds in the bread that give it a scrumptious texture and flavor.

The CHICKEN SALAD is my current favorite lunch sandwich. It's unlike your typical mayo-y, deli chicken salad - this refreshing chicken salad contains large pieces of chopped chicken with celery, sweet cranberries, and a whole grain mustard mayo that isn't applied too heavily. The lighter-take on everyone's favorite is served with tomato and greens on the multigrain bread!

I enjoyed the GENOA sandwich, but it wasn't my favorite. The roasted chicken is pulled and lightly tossed in pesto, and topped with roasted red peppers, tomato, pecorino, and artichoke aioli.  I can't speak to the bread, as I had it on the multi-grain (of course :P). I wish there were more pesto or aioli, as it ate a little dry and would have benefitted from some more sauce. 

Another delicious option is the HOUSE GRANOLA & YOGURT, which could be perfect any time of day. I'm not one to typically order this while out, since you can pretty much make it at home, but this was executed perfectly and I'd order it again. There it was a perfect ratio of ingredients, with a balance of granola and yogurt that was unmatched. Every bite had a perfect combination of both. The toppings added sweetness, crunchiness, and freshness, and I will certainly be ordering this again. 

I hope to try more of their sandwiches soon - I have my eye on the New Orleans and the Barcelona, but they seem a bit heavier so I've been waiting for the perfect day to order those. 

There's a reason (well, many actually) that I come back here time and time again. The food is good, the atmosphere is cozy, and it's simply a place I want to be.

Small space. They have seating right when you walk in, as well as upstairs. If it's even moderately full, or people come in to order a drink and wait, it can get very cramped quickly. There is not a lot of space to move around. 

Food is made fresh, and hence there can be a wait. I waited about 10 minutes or a bit longer. I spied the guy in the kitchen putting together my sandwiches, cooking ingredients. Thought that was cool. 

The guy who took the order wasn't rude or friendly, but just kind of...meh. Bland. As in, they're working, but don't give a damn about showing any kind of "customer service" vibe. However, I didn't come to chatter with the staff, I came for the food! 

I only ordered sandwiches, and I enjoyed all of them! 

Breakfast sandwich: Gooey fried eggs, that leaked a little yoke when biting into it. Perfect, and fun to soak up with the bun. Sandwich patty was clearly made in house, but smaller than the sandwich/bun, so you would definitely be eating egg, cheese, and bread alone for some of the bites. 

Egg white sandwich with roasted veggies, thin avocado slices, pepper aoli on whole grain bread. Kind of like an egg white omelette sandwich. Very hearty and filling. 

Caprese sandwich : best one! A little greens, tomato, generous amount of pesto, mozzarella, with a little drizzle of Balsamic. Had crunch, tang, acidity, nutty, herby...perfect. 

What I love about these sandwiches was that they were not thrown together hastily or messily, Even with a takeout order, there was time taken to layer everything right, cook everything right. Thoroughly enjoyed every bite and wish I lived locally so I could get them more often. 

A clean bathroom to use.

I was hoping not to do this. I reached out to management a week ago and they have been completely nonresponsive and negligent. I really wanted to leave the cafe name out of this because the situation is more important than the location, but I'm afraid they have given me no choice. I would like to protect future patrons from experiencing the same. 

A couple of weeks ago, I was at Plenty Cafe, a place I used to go to and study out of often. This is my story: 

It's finals week. Last night, I was working out of a café I go to often. A cafe known for being open late that many people use to study. It was late, and I was the only one in the space. At around 10, a group of three came into the space speaking loudly, above what one would consider normal. I turned to them and asked if they could keep it down a bit and they began to attack me.

The "gentleman", proceeded to yell at me. I responded by saying, it was just a question. I just asked a question. Then when he continued to harp on it, I insisted that I politely asked a question. Then he kept yelling "shut the fuck up". I defended myself and told him that he didn't need to say that to me and that I didn't need to "shut up". He then proceeded to call me a twat and insisted he was a gentleman for not breaking out the "C" word. Upon defending myself he told me that I had "control issues" and proceeded to yell at me and ask me if I was going to cry. I then told him that how he acts is on his conscious, and continued to work on my paper.

I refused to let someone terrorize me into leaving the space. I stayed, worked on my paper. While I was working he kept making up stories about my life with his buddies. First insisting that my loud typing was me talking to my boyfriend and then taking it back saying I probably didn't have a boyfriend. Then later saying that I didn't have friends. While upset, I kept working. I wasn't going to let him intimidate me. So I just ignored him and kept going. Upon leaving he talked about what else he could do to provoke me but ultimately left me alone. He then proceeded to complain about what had happened with the staff. After the group had left, the wait staff said nothing. I stayed until close, thanked them, and still nothing.

Since the election, I've felt afraid - as a woman and as a minority. I know there are bad people in this world, and while this upsets me, what upsets me more is that no one on the staff said anything. The older man was aggressively yelling "shut the fuck up" and "twat". At first I thought, well awkward situation to put yourself in the middle of but even after they left, no one asked me "Are you ok?" "I'm sorry that happened". They were silent. Silence is compliance.

These acts of hatred against women, against minorities, against LGBTQ, are happening all over the country. If you see something happening, please don't be quiet. Say something. At the very least, ask the person if they are ok.

I'm not that hard to please, I swear. I have been here a couple times now with similar experiences. The guy at the counter was pretty unfriendly and cold me to...I don't know if it was maybe that I took to long to look at the menu? Not sure...but he was extremely friendly to everyone after me so I don't know what I did - I'm sorry I'm not a regular but you can still at least be civil! I ordered the "new Orleans" and sat down with my book. 30 minutes later (yes. 30.) I thought I'd check on it, they literally just looked at me at said "oh. Yea....ready in a minute". (Place was not busy at all) Clearly forgotten and unapologetic. Another 5-8 minutes later the sandwich arrived with a halfhearted apology and a card for a free coffee. Thanks I guess ? Sandwich was quite good, though I still think the prices are a little high here. 

I should also mention my previous experience. Ordered the breakfast brisket sandwich and friend ordered bagel and lox/cream cheese. That also took about 20-25 minutes (not busy). Mine came first so I tried to take little bites till my friend got hers...never came and I was over half way through mine. Checked on hers and it was forgotten. No apology. Finally hers came and the guy said to me wait yours is the wrong brisket sandwich - after a lot of back and forth I said no this is the right one (they also have a different lunch/dinner brisket sandwich) but he literally tried to take my half eaten sandwich from in front of me because he was convicted I was wrong I had the wrong one. Really? Even if it was wrong are you really going take it from me at this point? 

I'm sorry...these experiences left a bad taste in my mouth. I think I'll be skipping Plenty Cafe from now on.

I looooove Plenty on East Passyunk Avenue, so I was absolutely stoked when their new location on Spruce Street finally opened last week. I parked the car illegally and stood watch while my partner in crime ran inside for breakfast sandwiches. 

My choice was the pancetta hash, with two fried eggs, pancetta, breakfast potatoes, and fontina. We got home and tore open our packages. Mine came in a cardboard to-go box, and when I opened the lid the first thing I noticed was the pool of egg yolk covering the entire bottom of the box, leaving the whole underside of my sandwich completely soaked and really messy. Meanwhile, the roll was really tough and also very large, and it overpowered (what was left of) the ingredients in the sandwich. If you do feel compelled to order the pancetta hash to go after reading this, be sure to order it with scrambled eggs. 

This was my first time ordering breakfast at Plenty; normally I have sandwiches and almost always the tasso ham panini, which is incredible. I'm looking forward to swinging by again soon, and hopefully updating my review once that happens.

A little surprised that there are so many 3 star reviews for this place, we thought it was at least a solid 4 star place, if it wasn't for a few issues it would be a 5.

The cons were the ambiance and layout of the place, it's super cramped and hot inside. We sat by the window at a little bar and they had just a ton of flowers at the bar, I and other patrons were having allergies as a result(and I usually love flowers). As more people piled in, the slowness behind the counter was really felt as everyone was just basically piled at the counter and front of the store, spilling into the area we were sitting. It took a pretty long time for our food to come out. They also didn't take names for orders, so everything was really disorganized and confusing. They forgot my husband's coffee for a pretty long time. Servers and staff behind the counter were not friendly, but honestly, try to consider how you'd feel if 20 impatient/hungry/thirsty people were all waiting for you. If anything, it seems like the place is understaffed and the layout compounds the issue.

In spite of all that, the food was truly wonderful. This was my favorite breakfast we had while we were in Philly. My husband had the frittata and I had the baked cheese(trying to stick to a lower carb option). The coffee was really good too, unlike a few other places we visited in the area.

As I read the first part of my review back to myself, it sounds more like 3 stars, but honestly the food is just that good. If you go in, just go in with a lot of patience and compassion for the folks working the understaffed counter, and take your food to go. With a to go order, I feel like it would be a 5.

VISIT HISTORY: 
- Last visit: Last Wednesday to do some administrative work 
- Frequency: Been here 2-3x now (with a group of friends to sit outside and hang, with a friend to study)
- Next visit? Due to proximity to my home, will be returning whenever I wanna do some work and don't want to go to Starbucks even though the Starbucks is way closer. 

FOODRINK:
- Pinot Gris: from Eugene, Oregon. Dry and semi-sweet. 
- Olives: I loooove olives. This was one of the most unique olives ever as it had picked cucumbers and random vegetables. Would definitely get it again! 

VIBE:
- I love coming here to get work done. It's a place that's halfway between regular cafe and a grown-up cafe. By grown-up cafe, I mean this is cafes only designed for executives and CEOs. 
- It's lofted so if you wanna look down at people and work upstairs, that's an option. 
- Staff is chill and helpful. 
- There's wifi. I resent cafes that don't have wifis. Luckily, I don't have that problem here. 
- Outlets: generous and convenient locations for outlets. This is my other let peeve for cafes. Luckily, I also don't have that problem here.
- There are 2-3 chairs of outdoor seating. On a nice sunny day, great spot to sit and people watch and hang out with people. 
- Wait time for foodrink arrival: almost immediate
- Wait time for our check: have to pay before getting the drinks

Definitely forgot to put plenty of smoked salmon in my breakfast sandwich.

I am a hardcore breakfast person. What I eat for breakfast determines how awesome my day will be. 

I requested that the eggs be sunny side up.. And epic fail for a sandwich that has nothing to hold it. Keep it scrambled. They give you a side of some salad which is two fingers worth, and there is absolutely nothing to hold this sandwich together...

It's a sinking ship here. But dat spiced chai tho... Was okay. 

Update: I returned here on 1/3/2015 because I believe you need to try a restaurant twice to really give an honest review. I ordered the machiatto and pesto chicken sandwich (see pics). This bumped up my review a star. One comment: the sizes of coffee and tea are pretty random, I know that most espresso drinks come in a smaller size traditionally --- but I would like to know the portion before I order as I'm a caffe veteran. 

Pros: I revisited this place on my last day in the city and it is fine for solo visitors - you don't need to show up with a group to eat here. There is plenty of room for single travelers.
